notes.N1:
HPI:
The patient is a 68 year-old female with CHF, hypertension and type 2 diabetes who was in her baseline state of health until 4 days ago when she began to notice decreased exercise tolerance and fatigue. Over the past several days these symptoms have worsened. Today she has had difficulty with shortness of breath, dry cough, and excessive fatigue. She has noticed swelling in her ankles for the past couple of days as well. She denies chest pain or fevers. 
 
She has been on a low-sodium diet, however she has stopped paying attention to it over the past week or so. She reports a prior episode of worsened respiratory distress with high salt intake earlier this year. Her blood sugars have been stable. 
 
She presented to the ED today for her shortness of breath where her CXR showed interstitial fluid, she had an elevated BNP, and she was found to be hypoxemic. She has been admitted for further diuresis and monitoring. 
 
Review Of Systems
Derm: negative
ENT: negative
Resp: shortness of breath, dyspnea on exertion, : pertinent negatives - cough, hemoptysis, pleuritic chest pain, wheezing
CV: palpitations, tachycardia and : pertinent negatives - chest pain
GI: negative
Endo: negative
Neuro: : pertinent negatives -   numbness, weakness, speech or visual changes, headaches, numbness or tingling
Psych: negative
 
Past Medical History:
She  has a past medical history of Essential hypertension (1985); Cluster headache, episodic (1988); Acquired hypothyroidism; Type II or unspecified type diabetes mellitus without mention of complication, not stated as uncontrolled (1/10/2005); CHF (congestive heart failure) (8/1/2011); and Depression.
 
Surgical History:
She  has past surgical history that includes appendectomy (1965) and remove tonsils/adenoids,[12 y/o (Age 12).
 
Social History:
She  reports that she quit smoking about 11 years ago. Her smoking use included Cigarettes. She has a 35 pack-year smoking history. She does not have any smokeless tobacco history on file. She reports that she drinks about 1.0 ounces of alcohol per week. She reports that she uses illicit drugs (marijuana).
 
 
Physical Exam 
Constitutional: She appears well-developed and well-nourished.
HENT: 
Head: Normocephalic and atraumatic. 
Mouth/Throat: Oropharynx is clear and moist. No oropharyngeal exudate.
Neck: Trachea normal and normal range of motion. Neck supple. JVD present. No hepatojugular reflux present. Carotid bruit is not present. No thyromegaly present. 
Cardiovascular: Regular rhythm and intact distal pulses.   No extrasystoles are present. Tachycardia present.  PMI is not displaced.  Exam reveals gallop.  
Murmur heard.
 Systolic murmur is present with a grade of 2/6
Pulmonary/Chest: Tachypnea noted. She has rales.
Abdominal: Soft. Bowel sounds are normal. She exhibits no distension.
Skin: There is pallor.
Psychiatric: She has a normal mood and affect. Her behavior is normal.
 
 
Assessment: 
68 y/o female with CHF exacerbation. 
 
Plan: 
Admit to medicine
IV furosemide scheduled bid for diuresis. Will adjust dose as per UOP. Electrolyte replacement as needed.
Telemetry monitoring and continuous pulse oximetry with oxygen via nasal cannula as needed.
Low-sodium diet with education.
Continue home medications as prescribed. Blood sugars with meals and at night. 
Morning electrolytes.
notes.N2:
History
HPI
The patient began to experience shortness of breath, fatigue, and has noticed swelling of her ankles for the past several days. She is typically on a low-sodium diet, but was at the Brewers baseball game yesterday where she "let it slip" and had 2 "The Beast" hot dogs with a couple chorizo sausages on the side. Her dyspnea is worsening and is worse with exercise. She denies chest pain, cough, or fever. She has had a similar experience with worsening respiratory symptoms when she has had a high salt diet in the past. 
 
 
Review of Systems
Constitutional: Positive for fatigue. Negative for fever.
HENT: Negative.  
Respiratory: Positive for shortness of breath. Negative for cough, chest tightness and wheezing.  
Cardiovascular: Positive for leg swelling. Negative for chest pain and palpitations.
Gastrointestinal: Negative.  Negative for abdominal distention. 
Endocrine: Negative.  
Skin: Negative for rash.
Neurological: Negative for syncope, weakness and light-headedness.
 
 
Physical Exam
BP 130/80 | Pulse 88 | Temp(Src) 37.2 °C (Oral) | Resp 24 | Ht 1.727 m | Wt 78 kg | BMI 26.15 kg/m2 | SpO2 92%
Physical Exam 
Vitals reviewed.
Constitutional: She appears well-developed and well-nourished.
HENT: 
Mouth/Throat: No oropharyngeal exudate.
Eyes: No scleral icterus.
Neck: JVD present. No thyromegaly present. 
Cardiovascular: Normal rate and regular rhythm.  Exam reveals gallop.  
Murmur heard.
Pulmonary/Chest: She has rales (lung bases bilaterally). She exhibits no tenderness.
Abdominal: Soft. She exhibits no distension. There is no tenderness. 
Musculoskeletal: She exhibits edema (ankle edema blaterally). 
Lymphadenopathy: 
  She has no cervical adenopathy. 
Skin: There is pallor.
Psychiatric: Her behavior is normal. Judgment normal.
 
 
ED Course
Procedures
The patient was found to be hypoxemic on presentation with tachypnea and tachycardia. Her oxygenation improved on nasal cannula oxygen. A CXR shows bilateral interstitial markings with a developing pleural effusion on the left. ECG shows no signs of ischemia and his troponins are normal. Her BNP is elevated, consistent with an exacerbation of his CHF. 
 
She was given IV furosemide with brisk UOP response, but her respiratory status remains unchanged with tachypnea and an oxygen requirement. 
 
Given her ongoing signs of respiratory compromise, the patient will be admitted for further assessment and monitoring. 
 
MDM

summary: During Kim Pope's hospital stay on 8/7/2024, they were admitted due to worsening symptoms of chronic systolic congestive heart failure, including shortness of breath, fatigue, and ankle swelling, exacerbated by non-compliance with a low-sodium diet [N1, N2]. Diagnostic tests revealed elevated B-type natriuretic peptide levels, hypoxemia, and interstitial fluid on chest X-ray, indicating heart failure exacerbation [O2, O6, O7]. Despite treatment with IV furosemide for diuresis, their respiratory status did not return to baseline, necessitating continued monitoring and management [N2]. The care plan included electrolyte management, telemetry monitoring, oxygen support, and education on dietary compliance, alongside their regular medications [N1].
